Executive Summary

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies
The Company has developed a risk management plan, evaluated process hazards and reviewed the design and construction of the ammonia and chlorine systems to ensure that they are safe to operate.  Employees participated in the system review and process hazards analysis.  The Company has trained and properly equipped its employees who will be responding to potential releases from the these systems.  Also, the Company's emergency response plan provides for notification of outside emergency responders to give on-site assistance and/or emergency evacuation/shelter-in-place notification of affected residents in the event of an ammonia or chlorine release.
Stationary source and regulated substance handled
The Ameren Energy Generating Coffeen Power Plant is located in Montgomery County, Illinois, approximately 2.5 miles southeast of the city of Coffeen. Coffeen plant began producing electricity in 1965. Coffeen plant has been chlorinating its circulating water for the past 34 years without any significant releases or injuries. The chlorination system has been periodically upgraded, and safely used one ton cylinders of chlorine for the last six years. The plant typically uses 60,000 pounds of chlorine each year to prevent biofouling of condensers and other equipment from water drawn out of Lake Coffeen. Chlorine is added to the water for about ten minutes, twelve times daily. The system is checked at least three times daily by operations. Leack checks are also done whenever a new bank of cylinders is placed into service. The chlorine cylinders are located within a fenced area near the plant entrance. The system has leak detectors, as well as alarms to warn of any process deviations.  
The plant began the process of installing a selective catalytic reduction unit (SCR) on one of its two coal-fired units in the fall of 2001. The newly installed SCR unit will begin commercial operation during

the ozone season, May through September of 2002. As a part of the SCR unit, an anhydrous ammonia injection system has been installed to supply ammonia gas to the SCR (Selective Catalytic Reduction) system for the purpose of NOx (nitrogen oxides) emissions control. Commercial grade anhydrous ammonia (99.5% or higher purity with a maximum water content of 0.5%) is required for this system.  The ammonia is stored in two 50,000-gallon tanks. From these storage tanks, the anhydrous ammonia is pumped to a vaporizer, if need be. Under most conditions, the ammonia will have enough pressure that the pumps are bypassed, and the ammonia flow is directly to the vaporizer. The vaporizer uses steam to vaporize the ammonia. Ammonia gas then passes through a line to the mixing chamber where it is diluted with air. This ammonia and dilution air mixture is piped to the distribution header and injected directly into the exhaust gas. As the treated exhaust gas flows over the SCR catalyst bed, the NOx is reduced to nitrogen (N2) and water vapor.
Worst-case release scenario and alternative-case release scenario, including administrative controls and mitigation measures
The worst case release scenario for chlorine involves the release of 2000 pounds within ten minutes producing a vapor cloud that is predicted to travel offsite for a distance of 3.0 miles before reaching safe levels.
The worst case release scenario involves the loss of 219300 pounds of anhydrous ammonia within ten minutes due to liquid spill and vaporization.  The resulting vapor cloud is predicted to travel off-site for a distance of 4.3 miles before reaching safe levels.
The alternative case scenario for chlorine is a pipe leak that releases 8240 pounds within two minutes producing a vapor cloud predicted to travel a distance of 2.5 miles before reaching safe levels.
The alternative case scenario is a release of 10377 pounds of anhydrous ammonia within a ten minutes due to the rupture of a 2 inch supply line from t

he storage tanks to the vaporizer.  The resulting vapor cloud is predicted to travel for a distance of 1.1 miles before reaching safe levels.
The only mitigation measures associated with the chlorine system are chlorine detectors around the process area. 
The anhydrous ammonia system has 8 sensors to detect any ammonia leaks, and 12 spray nozzles that will automatically activate to minimize the possibility of a catastrophic release of ammonia from the tank and feed system. There are also pressure relief valves on the storage tanks, as well as, flow control valves to sense changes in flow, and automatically close. The 50,000-gallon ammonia storage tanks are located so that accidental contact is unlikely. An emergency shower/eyewash facility is located at the unloading area, and guardrails are installed to prevent vehicular contact during unloading activities. Also, the Company has developed administrative controls to monitor the ammonia filling process to reduce the likelihood of a release during that operation.
General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
The ammonia system was purchased from Chemithon, Seattle, WA.  Chemithon has designed and supplied this system to safely store, handle and deliver the ammonia product to the SCR system. 
The importance of preventing any releases is stressed through on the job and formal classroom training.  Company personnel will adhere to the system vendor's operations and maintenance procedures that are based on acceptable industry standards. 

Five-year accident history
This system is new and has no data to report.

Emergency response program
Company employees who have been properly trained and equipped with the necessary personal protective equipment and tools will respond to an ammonia or chlorine release initially.  If the leak cannot be isolated, and outside assistance is deemed necessary, the Company will notify 911. This will trigger notification of the Coffeen Fire Depart

ment to begin evacuation procedures of the surrounding area.  The Ambulance Service, Montgomery County's Sheriff Department, Illinois State Police Hazmat Team, the Montgomery County Emergency Service Disaster Agency (ESDA), and the Illinois Emergency Management Association (IEMA) would also be notified by the 911 coordinator.
Planned changes to improve safety
The process will be audited and systems will be inspected regularly to ensure that it remains safe to operate.  The Company has implemented a Management of Change procedure to evaluate the safety and adequacy of any changes that may have to be made to the system.
